10870Journal of Chemical CrystallographyJ Chem Crystallogr1074-15421572-8854Springer USBostons10870-010-9772-0977210.1007/s10870-010-9772-0Original PaperSynthesis and Crystal Structures of Anionic Gallium(II) and Gallium(III) Heterocyclic Compounds Derived from a Gallium(I) N-Heterocyclic Carbene AnalogueJonesCameron1aMillsDavid P.1RivardEric1StaschAndreas1WoodulWilliam D.1grid.1002.30000000419367857School of ChemistryMonash UniversityPO Box 233800MelbourneVICAustralia+61-3-9902-0391+61-3-9905-4597cameron.jones@sci.monash.edu.au22520101120104011965969105201045201010520102252010© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20102010Abstract

The addition of the N–H bond of the formamidine, ArN(H)C=NAr (Ar = C6H3Pr2i-2,6), to the gallium(I) center of [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)] (Ar-DAB={(Ar)NC(H)}2) yields K[(Ar-DAB)GaIII(H){N(Ar)C=NAr}] 1. The crystal structure of this and two other related anionic compounds, [K(18-crown-6)][(Ar-DAB)GaIII{N(H)N=Fl}{(H)Fl}] (Fl = fluorendiyl) 2 and [K(OEt2)3][(Ar-DAB)GaII(CH2Ph)GaII(Ar-DAB)] 3, have been determined. The cell parameters of the compounds are 1: P21/c, a = 20.2350(9), b = 14.1760(7), c = 19.6441(10), β = 111.307(1); 2: P21/c, a = 13.115(3), b = 21.799(4), c = 22.646(5), β = 90.20(3); 3: P21/n, a = 16.783(3), b = 21.635(4), c = 19.814(4), β = 92.34(3). The crystal structures of all complexes exhibit distorted tetrahedral gallium centers, and interactions between anion aryl substituents and the potassium cations.

Graphical Abstract

The crystal structures of three anionic gallium(II or III) heterocyclic compounds, derived from oxidation reactions of a gallium(I) heterocycle salt, [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)] (Ar-DAB = {(C6H3Pr2i-2,6)NC(H)}2), are reported.

KeywordsGallium(I)HeterocycleOxidationN-heterocyclic carbene analoguevolume-issue-count12issue-article-count30issue-toc-levels0issue-pricelist-year2010issue-copyright-holderSpringer Science+Business Media, LLCissue-copyright-year2010article-contains-esmNoarticle-numbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-registration-date-year2010article-registration-date-month5article-registration-date-day10article-toc-levels0toc-levels0volume-typeRegularjournal-productNonStandardArchiveJournalnumbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-grants-typeRegularmetadata-grantOpenAccessabstract-grantOpenAccessbodypdf-grantRestrictedbodyhtml-grantRestrictedbibliography-grantRestrictedesm-grantOpenAccessonline-firstfalsepdf-file-referenceBodyRef/PDF/10870_2010_Article_9772.pdftarget-typeOnlinePDFissue-online-date-year2010issue-online-date-month11issue-online-date-day4issue-print-date-year2010issue-print-date-month10issue-print-date-day28issue-typeRegulararticle-typeOriginalPaperjournal-subject-primaryChemistryjournal-subject-secondaryInorganic Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryPhysical Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryCrystallographyjournal-subject-secondaryOrganometallic Chemistry open-accessfalseIntroduction

In 2002, we reported the preparation of the anionic gallium(I) heterocycle, [:Ga(Ar-DAB)]− (Ar-DAB = {N(Ar)C(H)}2; Ar = C6H3Pr2i-2,6), which is a valence isoelectronic analogue of the important N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) class of ligand [1]. The synthetic versatility of this heterocycle has been amply demonstrated by its use as a Ga-donor ligand in the formation of complexes with more than 45 elements from all blocks of the periodic table [see for example, 2–9]. Throughout this work, the coordination chemistry of the heterocycle has shown similarities, but also significant differences, with that of NHCs, gallium diyls (:GaIR) [10] and neutral gallium(I) heterocycles, e.g., six-membered [:Ga(Nacnac)] (Nacnac = {N(Ar)C(Me)}2CH) [see for example, 11, 12] and four-membered [:Ga(Giso)] (Giso = {N(Ar)}2CNCy2, Cy = cyclohexyl) [see for example, 13, 14]. The heterocycle, [:Ga(Ar-DAB)]−, is a strong σ-donor ligand (having a largely sp-hybridized Ga lone pair), but a weak π-acceptor. We have previously observed that its GaI center can activate C–H bonds [15] and we now demonstrate its insertion into an N–H bond for the first time. The structure of the anionic gallium(III) hydride product is polymeric and possesses a distorted tetrahedral gallium center, as do the structures of two related oxidation products described herein.

ExperimentalCompound Preparations

All manipulations were carried out using standard Schlenk and glove box techniques under an atmosphere of high purity dinitrogen. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DXP300 spectrometer and were referenced to the resonances of the solvent used. Mass spectra were obtained from the EPSRC National Mass Spectrometric Service at Swansea University. Microanalyses were carried out by Campbell Microanalytical, Ottago. Melting points were determined in sealed glass capillaries under dinitrogen and are uncorrected. The compound [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)] was prepared by the literature method [1], whilst all other reagents were used as received.

Preparation of K[(Ar-DAB)GaIII(H){N(Ar)C=NAr}] 1. A solution of [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)] (0.30 g, 0.49 mmol) in THF (10 cm3) was added to a solution of ArN(H)C=NAr (0.18 g, 0.49 mmol) in THF (10 cm3) at −78 °C. The orange reaction mixture was warmed to 20 °C and stirred for 1 h. Volatiles were then removed in vacuo and the residue was extracted into toluene (50 cm3) and filtered. The filtrate was concentrated to ca. 5 cm3 and stored at −30 °C overnight to give pale yellow crystals of 1. A second crop was obtained (0.11 g, 26%). Mp 171–173 °C (decomp.); 1H NMR (300 MHz, C6D6, 298 K): δ 1.02–1.67 (m, 48 H, CH(CH3)2), 3.21 (sept., 3JHH = 6.8 Hz, 2 H, CH(CH3)2), 3.51 (sept., 3JHH = 6.5 Hz, 6 H, CH(CH3)2), 7.02–7.25 (m, 14 H, NCH and Ar–H), Ga-H not observed; MS (EI), m/z (%): 445 (Ga(DAB)H+, 100), 377 (DABH+, 75); IR v/cm−1 (Nujol): 1878 br., s (Ga-H str.), 1665 s, 1595 s, 1563 s, 1354 s, 1316 m, 1256 m, 1210 m, 1100 m, 757 m.

Compound 2, [K(18-crown-6)][(Ar-DAB)GaIII{N(H)N=Fl}{(H)Fl}] (Fl = fluorendiyl), was obtained in low yield (9%) from the 1:2 reaction of [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)] with 9-diazofluorene (FlN2) in toluene in the presence of an excess of 18-crown-6 at 25 °C. Deep green crystals of 2 deposited from the reaction mixture after 2 h. At present, the mechanism of formation of 2 is unknown but presumably involves hydrogen abstraction from the reaction solvent. The compound displays negligible solubility in normal deuterated solvents. As a result meaningful NMR spectroscopic data for the compound could not be obtained. Mp 93–96 °C (decomp.); MS (EI), m/z (%): 445 (Ga(Ar-DAB)H+, 100), 377 (Ar-DABH+, 63); IR v/cm−1 (Nujol): 3365 m (N–H str.), 1666 s, 1593 s, 1563 s, 1355 s, 1316 m, 1256 m, 1210 m, 757 m; anal. calc. for C71H86N4GaKO6: C 71.05%, H 7.22%, N 4.67%; found: C 70.56%, H 7.01%, N 4.64%.

Compound 3, [K(OEt2)3][(Ar-DAB)GaII(CH2Ph)GaII(Ar-DAB)], was obtained in low yield (6%) from the 1:1 reaction of [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)] with [BrB(Ar-DAB)] in a mixture of diethyl ether and toluene at 25 °C. Deep red crystals of 3 deposited from the reaction mixture after 5 h. At present, the mechanism of formation of 3 is unknown, but it likely involves oxidation of the gallium(I) starting material by [BrB(Ar-DAB)] to give the known gallium(II) dimer, [{Ga(Ar-DAB)}2] [16]. The toluene solvent could then be deprotonated by an excess of the base, [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)], yielding K[CH2Ph] which reacts with [{Ga(Ar-DAB)}2] to give compound 3. The compound displays negligible solubility in normal deuterated solvents. As a result meaningful NMR spectroscopic data for the compound could not be obtained. Mp 205–209 °C (decomp.); MS (EI), m/z (%): 889 ({Ga(Ar-DAB)}2H, 23), 445 (Ga(Ar-DAB)H+, 100), 377 (Ar-DABH+, 42); IR v/cm−1 (Nujol): 1666 w, 1587 s, 1351 s, 1316 m, 1259 m, 1098 s, 800 s, 758 m; anal. calc. for C71H109N4Ga2KO3: C 68.48%, H 8.82%, N 4.50%; found: C 68.12%, H 8.71%, N 4.48%.

Crystal Structure Determinations

Crystals of 1–3 suitable for X-ray structural determination were mounted in silicone oil. Crystallographic measurements were made on a Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer using a graphite monochromator with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The data were collected at 123 K and the structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by full matrix least squares (SHELX97) [17] using all unique data. The majority of the hydrogen atoms of the structures are included in calculated positions (riding model). However, H(1a) in the structure of 1, and H(3) and H(27) in the structure of 2, were refined isotropically with no restraints on their positional parameters. Selected crystallographic and refinement details are given in Table 1.

Results and Discussion

Line drawings of compounds 1–3 can be found in Fig. 1, while their molecular structures are depicted in Figs. 2, 3, and 4. Selected metrical parameters for the compounds are given in Table 2. Compound 1 is formed by the oxidative addition of the N–H bond of the formamidine, ArN(H)C=NAr, to the GaI center of [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)]. Similar addition reactions have only recently been reported [18]. The crystal structure of 1 includes a molecule of toluene of crystallization in the asymmetric unit which is disordered over two sites in a 50:50 ratio. The carbon atoms of the two disordered sets were refined isotropically. Compound 1 possesses a distorted tetrahedral gallium center which is coordinated by three N-centers and a hydride ligand, which was located from difference maps and refined isotropically. The intra-ring geometry of the Ga heterocycle is similar to that in 2 and 3 and is consistent with it containing localized N–C and Ga–N single, and C=C double bonds. Interestingly, the Ar-substituent on N(1) is bent significantly away from the GaN2C2 least squares plane by an angle of 32.7(2)°, presumably because of steric buttressing with the Ar substituent on N(3). A similar situation has previously been observed in the related gallium hydride complex, [(Ar-DAB)Ga(H)(IMes)] (IMes = :C{N(C3H2Me3-2,4,6)C(H)}2) [15]. The potassium cation in the structure of 1 is coordinated in a κ1-N,η6-Ar fashion by the ArNC=NAr ligand, while monomeric units of 1 are assembled into linear polymeric chains by an additional intermolecular η6-coordination to the K-center by the Ar substituent on N(2) (not shown in Fig. 2).

A molecule of toluene of crystallization is present in the asymmetric unit of the crystal structure of compound 2. The compound has a distorted tetrahedral GaIII-center which is chelated by a dianionic Ar-DAB ligand, in addition to being coordinated by a fluorenyl group and an [FlN2H]− anion, the geometric parameters of which suggest it contains a localized (H)NN=C fragment. The potassium counter-ion in the structure is coordinated in a κ6-fashion by a molecule of 18-crown-6, in addition to having an approximately η3-interaction with the C(31), C(32) and C(33) atoms of the fluorenyl group.

In the solid state, compound 3 possesses two GaII centers that are connected by a Ga–Ga bond, the length of which is in the known range for digallane(4) species (2.332–2.584 Å),1 but longer than that in the related neutral compound, [(Ar-DAB)GaGa(Ar-DAB)] (2.3482(2) Å) [16]. One gallium center of 2, Ga(2), has a distorted trigonal planar geometry, while the other, Ga(1), is additionally coordinated by a benzyl anion, giving it a distorted tetrahedral geometry. The potassium counter-ion has an η6-interaction with this benzyl group and is further coordinated by three molecules of diethyl ether.

Supplementary Material

Supplementary crystallographic data for 1 (CCDC-775683), 2 (CCDC-775684) and 3 (CCDC-775685) can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk, or by contacting The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 IEZ, UK; Fax: +44-1223-336033.

One gallium center of 2, Ga(2), has a distorted trigonal planar geometry, while the other, Ga(1), is additionally coordinated by a benzyl anion, giving it a distorted tetrahedral geometry. The potassium counter-ion has an η6-interaction with this benzyl group and is further coordinated by three molecules of diethyl ether.Supplementary MaterialSupplementary crystallographic data for 1 (CCDC-775683), 2 (CCDC-775684) and 3 (CCDC-775685) can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk, or by contacting The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 IEZ, UK; Fax: +44-1223-336033.AcknowledgementsThe authors gratefully acknowledge financial support from the Australian Research Council (Fellowships for CJ, AS and ER). elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The addition of the N-H bond of the formamidine, ArN(H)C=NAr (Ar = C6H3Pr2i-2,6), to the gallium(I) center of [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)] (Ar-DAB={(Ar)NC(H)}2) yields K[(Ar-DAB)GaIII(H){N(Ar)C=NAr}] 1. The crystal structure of this and two other related anionic compounds, [K(18-crown-6)][(Ar-DAB)GaIII{N(H)N=Fl}{(H)Fl}] (Fl = fluorendiyl) 2 and [K(OEt2)3][(Ar-DAB)GaII(CH2Ph)GaII(Ar-DAB)] 3, have been determined. The cell parameters of the compounds are 1: P21/c, a = 20.2350(9), b = 14.1760(7), c = 19.6441(10), β = 111.307(1); 2: P21/c, a = 13.115(3), b = 21.799(4), c = 22.646(5), β = 90.20(3); 3: P21/n, a = 16.783(3), b = 21.635(4), c = 19.814(4), β = 92.34(3). The crystal structures of all complexes exhibit distorted tetrahedral gallium centers, and interactions between anion aryl substituents and the potassium cations.

elements.content: The crystal structures of three anionic gallium(II or III) heterocyclic compounds, derived from oxidation reactions of a gallium(I) heterocycle salt, [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)] (Ar-DAB = {(C6H3Pr2i-2,6)NC(H)}2), are reported.
elements.clean_text:
Graphical Abstract

The crystal structures of three anionic gallium(II or III) heterocyclic compounds, derived from oxidation reactions of a gallium(I) heterocycle salt, [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)] (Ar-DAB = {(C6H3Pr2i-2,6)NC(H)}2), are reported.

elements.content: In 2002, we reported the preparation of the anionic gallium(I) heterocycle, [:Ga(Ar-DAB)]− (Ar-DAB = {N(Ar)C(H)}2; Ar = C6H3Pr2i-2,6), which is a valence isoelectronic analogue of the important N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) class of ligand [1]. The synthetic versatility of this heterocycle has been amply demonstrated by its use as a Ga-donor ligand in the formation of complexes with more than 45 elements from all blocks of the periodic table [see for example, 2–9]. Throughout this work, the coordination chemistry of the heterocycle has shown similarities, but also significant differences, with that of NHCs, gallium diyls (:GaIR) [10] and neutral gallium(I) heterocycles, e.g., six-membered [:Ga(Nacnac)] (Nacnac = {N(Ar)C(Me)}2CH) [see for example, 11, 12] and four-membered [:Ga(Giso)] (Giso = {N(Ar)}2CNCy2, Cy = cyclohexyl) [see for example, 13, 14]. The heterocycle, [:Ga(Ar-DAB)]−, is a strong σ-donor ligand (having a largely sp-hybridized Ga lone pair), but a weak π-acceptor. We have previously observed that its GaI center can activate C–H bonds [15] and we now demonstrate its insertion into an N–H bond for the first time. The structure of the anionic gallium(III) hydride product is polymeric and possesses a distorted tetrahedral gallium center, as do the structures of two related oxidation products described herein.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In 2002, we reported the preparation of the anionic gallium(I) heterocycle, [:Ga(Ar-DAB)]- (Ar-DAB = {N(Ar)C(H)}2; Ar = C6H3Pr2i-2,6), which is a valence isoelectronic analogue of the important N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) class of ligand [1]. The synthetic versatility of this heterocycle has been amply demonstrated by its use as a Ga-donor ligand in the formation of complexes with more than 45 elements from all blocks of the periodic table [see for example, 2-9]. Throughout this work, the coordination chemistry of the heterocycle has shown similarities, but also significant differences, with that of NHCs, gallium diyls (:GaIR) [10] and neutral gallium(I) heterocycles, e.g., six-membered [:Ga(Nacnac)] (Nacnac = {N(Ar)C(Me)}2CH) [see for example, 11, 12] and four-membered [:Ga(Giso)] (Giso = {N(Ar)}2CNCy2, Cy = cyclohexyl) [see for example, 13, 14]. The heterocycle, [:Ga(Ar-DAB)]-, is a strong σ-donor ligand (having a largely sp-hybridized Ga lone pair), but a weak π-acceptor. We have previously observed that its GaI center can activate C-H bonds [15] and we now demonstrate its insertion into an N-H bond for the first time. The structure of the anionic gallium(III) hydride product is polymeric and possesses a distorted tetrahedral gallium center, as do the structures of two related oxidation products described herein.

elements.content: All manipulations were carried out using standard Schlenk and glove box techniques under an atmosphere of high purity dinitrogen. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DXP300 spectrometer and were referenced to the resonances of the solvent used. Mass spectra were obtained from the EPSRC National Mass Spectrometric Service at Swansea University. Microanalyses were carried out by Campbell Microanalytical, Ottago. Melting points were determined in sealed glass capillaries under dinitrogen and are uncorrected. The compound [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)] was prepared by the literature method [1], whilst all other reagents were used as received.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Compound Preparations

All manipulations were carried out using standard Schlenk and glove box techniques under an atmosphere of high purity dinitrogen. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DXP300 spectrometer and were referenced to the resonances of the solvent used. Mass spectra were obtained from the EPSRC National Mass Spectrometric Service at Swansea University. Microanalyses were carried out by Campbell Microanalytical, Ottago. Melting points were determined in sealed glass capillaries under dinitrogen and are uncorrected. The compound [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)] was prepared by the literature method [1], whilst all other reagents were used as received.

elements.content: Preparation of K[(Ar-DAB)GaIII(H){N(Ar)C=NAr}] 1. A solution of [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)] (0.30 g, 0.49 mmol) in THF (10 cm3) was added to a solution of ArN(H)C=NAr (0.18 g, 0.49 mmol) in THF (10 cm3) at −78 °C. The orange reaction mixture was warmed to 20 °C and stirred for 1 h. Volatiles were then removed in vacuo and the residue was extracted into toluene (50 cm3) and filtered. The filtrate was concentrated to ca. 5 cm3 and stored at −30 °C overnight to give pale yellow crystals of 1. A second crop was obtained (0.11 g, 26%). Mp 171–173 °C (decomp.); 1H NMR (300 MHz, C6D6, 298 K): δ 1.02–1.67 (m, 48 H, CH(CH3)2), 3.21 (sept., 3JHH = 6.8 Hz, 2 H, CH(CH3)2), 3.51 (sept., 3JHH = 6.5 Hz, 6 H, CH(CH3)2), 7.02–7.25 (m, 14 H, NCH and Ar–H), Ga-H not observed; MS (EI), m/z (%): 445 (Ga(DAB)H+, 100), 377 (DABH+, 75); IR v/cm−1 (Nujol): 1878 br., s (Ga-H str.), 1665 s, 1595 s, 1563 s, 1354 s, 1316 m, 1256 m, 1210 m, 1100 m, 757 m.

elements.content: Compound 2, [K(18-crown-6)][(Ar-DAB)GaIII{N(H)N=Fl}{(H)Fl}] (Fl = fluorendiyl), was obtained in low yield (9%) from the 1:2 reaction of [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)] with 9-diazofluorene (FlN2) in toluene in the presence of an excess of 18-crown-6 at 25 °C. Deep green crystals of 2 deposited from the reaction mixture after 2 h. At present, the mechanism of formation of 2 is unknown but presumably involves hydrogen abstraction from the reaction solvent. The compound displays negligible solubility in normal deuterated solvents. As a result meaningful NMR spectroscopic data for the compound could not be obtained. Mp 93–96 °C (decomp.); MS (EI), m/z (%): 445 (Ga(Ar-DAB)H+, 100), 377 (Ar-DABH+, 63); IR v/cm−1 (Nujol): 3365 m (N–H str.), 1666 s, 1593 s, 1563 s, 1355 s, 1316 m, 1256 m, 1210 m, 757 m; anal. calc. for C71H86N4GaKO6: C 71.05%, H 7.22%, N 4.67%; found: C 70.56%, H 7.01%, N 4.64%.

elements.content: Compound 3, [K(OEt2)3][(Ar-DAB)GaII(CH2Ph)GaII(Ar-DAB)], was obtained in low yield (6%) from the 1:1 reaction of [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)] with [BrB(Ar-DAB)] in a mixture of diethyl ether and toluene at 25 °C. Deep red crystals of 3 deposited from the reaction mixture after 5 h. At present, the mechanism of formation of 3 is unknown, but it likely involves oxidation of the gallium(I) starting material by [BrB(Ar-DAB)] to give the known gallium(II) dimer, [{Ga(Ar-DAB)}2] [16]. The toluene solvent could then be deprotonated by an excess of the base, [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)], yielding K[CH2Ph] which reacts with [{Ga(Ar-DAB)}2] to give compound 3. The compound displays negligible solubility in normal deuterated solvents. As a result meaningful NMR spectroscopic data for the compound could not be obtained. Mp 205–209 °C (decomp.); MS (EI), m/z (%): 889 ({Ga(Ar-DAB)}2H, 23), 445 (Ga(Ar-DAB)H+, 100), 377 (Ar-DABH+, 42); IR v/cm−1 (Nujol): 1666 w, 1587 s, 1351 s, 1316 m, 1259 m, 1098 s, 800 s, 758 m; anal. calc. for C71H109N4Ga2KO3: C 68.48%, H 8.82%, N 4.50%; found: C 68.12%, H 8.71%, N 4.48%.

elements.content: Crystals of 1–3 suitable for X-ray structural determination were mounted in silicone oil. Crystallographic measurements were made on a Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer using a graphite monochromator with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The data were collected at 123 K and the structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by full matrix least squares (SHELX97) [17] using all unique data. The majority of the hydrogen atoms of the structures are included in calculated positions (riding model). However, H(1a) in the structure of 1, and H(3) and H(27) in the structure of 2, were refined isotropically with no restraints on their positional parameters. Selected crystallographic and refinement details are given in Table 1.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determinations

Crystals of 1-3 suitable for X-ray structural determination were mounted in silicone oil. Crystallographic measurements were made on a Nonius Kappa CCD diffractometer using a graphite monochromator with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The data were collected at 123 K and the structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by full matrix least squares (SHELX97) [17] using all unique data. The majority of the hydrogen atoms of the structures are included in calculated positions (riding model). However, H(1a) in the structure of 1, and H(3) and H(27) in the structure of 2, were refined isotropically with no restraints on their positional parameters. Selected crystallographic and refinement details are given in Table 1.

Line drawings of compounds 1–3 can be found in Fig. 1, while their molecular structures are depicted in Figs. 2, 3, and 4. Selected metrical parameters for the compounds are given in Table 2. Compound 1 is formed by the oxidative addition of the N–H bond of the formamidine, ArN(H)C=NAr, to the GaI center of [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)]. Similar addition reactions have only recently been reported [18]. The crystal structure of 1 includes a molecule of toluene of crystallization in the asymmetric unit which is disordered over two sites in a 50:50 ratio. The carbon atoms of the two disordered sets were refined isotropically. Compound 1 possesses a distorted tetrahedral gallium center which is coordinated by three N-centers and a hydride ligand, which was located from difference maps and refined isotropically. The intra-ring geometry of the Ga heterocycle is similar to that in 2 and 3 and is consistent with it containing localized N–C and Ga–N single, and C=C double bonds. Interestingly, the Ar-substituent on N(1) is bent significantly away from the GaN2C2 least squares plane by an angle of 32.7(2)°, presumably because of steric buttressing with the Ar substituent on N(3). A similar situation has previously been observed in the related gallium hydride complex, [(Ar-DAB)Ga(H)(IMes)] (IMes = :C{N(C3H2Me3-2,4,6)C(H)}2) [15]. The potassium cation in the structure of 1 is coordinated in a κ1-N,η6-Ar fashion by the ArNC=NAr ligand, while monomeric units of 1 are assembled into linear polymeric chains by an additional intermolecular η6-coordination to the K-center by the Ar substituent on N(2) (not shown in Fig. 2).

Results and Discussion

Line drawings of compounds 1-3 can be found in Fig. 1, while their molecular structures are depicted in Figs. 2, 3, and 4. Selected metrical parameters for the compounds are given in Table 2. Compound 1 is formed by the oxidative addition of the N-H bond of the formamidine, ArN(H)C=NAr, to the GaI center of [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)]. Similar addition reactions have only recently been reported [18]. The crystal structure of 1 includes a molecule of toluene of crystallization in the asymmetric unit which is disordered over two sites in a 50:50 ratio. The carbon atoms of the two disordered sets were refined isotropically. Compound 1 possesses a distorted tetrahedral gallium center which is coordinated by three N-centers and a hydride ligand, which was located from difference maps and refined isotropically. The intra-ring geometry of the Ga heterocycle is similar to that in 2 and 3 and is consistent with it containing localized N-C and Ga-N single, and C=C double bonds. Interestingly, the Ar-substituent on N(1) is bent significantly away from the GaN2C2 least squares plane by an angle of 32.7(2)°, presumably because of steric buttressing with the Ar substituent on N(3). A similar situation has previously been observed in the related gallium hydride complex, [(Ar-DAB)Ga(H)(IMes)] (IMes = :C{N(C3H2Me3-2,4,6)C(H)}2) [15]. The potassium cation in the structure of 1 is coordinated in a κ1-N,η6-Ar fashion by the ArNC=NAr ligand, while monomeric units of 1 are assembled into linear polymeric chains by an additional intermolecular η6-coordination to the K-center by the Ar substituent on N(2) (not shown in Fig. 2).

A molecule of toluene of crystallization is present in the asymmetric unit of the crystal structure of compound 2. The compound has a distorted tetrahedral GaIII-center which is chelated by a dianionic Ar-DAB ligand, in addition to being coordinated by a fluorenyl group and an [FlN2H]− anion, the geometric parameters of which suggest it contains a localized (H)NN=C fragment. The potassium counter-ion in the structure is coordinated in a κ6-fashion by a molecule of 18-crown-6, in addition to having an approximately η3-interaction with the C(31), C(32) and C(33) atoms of the fluorenyl group.

The compound has a distorted tetrahedral GaIII-center which is chelated by a dianionic Ar-DAB ligand, in addition to being coordinated by a fluorenyl group and an [FlN2H]- anion, the geometric parameters of which suggest it contains a localized (H)NN=C fragment. The potassium counter-ion in the structure is coordinated in a κ6-fashion by a molecule of 18-crown-6, in addition to having an approximately η3-interaction with the C(31), C(32) and C(33) atoms of the fluorenyl group.

elements.content: In the solid state, compound 3 possesses two GaII centers that are connected by a Ga–Ga bond, the length of which is in the known range for digallane(4) species (2.332–2.584 Å),1 but longer than that in the related neutral compound, [(Ar-DAB)GaGa(Ar-DAB)] (2.3482(2) Å) [16]. One gallium center of 2, Ga(2), has a distorted trigonal planar geometry, while the other, Ga(1), is additionally coordinated by a benzyl anion, giving it a distorted tetrahedral geometry. The potassium counter-ion has an η6-interaction with this benzyl group and is further coordinated by three molecules of diethyl ether.

One gallium center of 2, Ga(2), has a distorted trigonal planar geometry, while the other, Ga(1), is additionally coordinated by a benzyl anion, giving it a distorted tetrahedral geometry. The potassium counter-ion has an η6-interaction with this benzyl group and is further coordinated by three molecules of diethyl ether.

cln_elements.content:
Preparation of K[(Ar-DAB)GaIII(H){N(Ar)C=NAr}] 1. A solution of [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)] (0.30 g, 0.49 mmol) in THF (10 cm3) was added to a solution of ArN(H)C=NAr (0.18 g, 0.49 mmol) in THF (10 cm3) at −78 °C. The orange reaction mixture was warmed to 20 °C and stirred for 1 h. Volatiles were then removed in vacuo and the residue was extracted into toluene (50 cm3) and filtered. The filtrate was concentrated to ca. 5 cm3 and stored at −30 °C overnight to give pale yellow crystals of 1. A second crop was obtained (0.11 g, 26%). Mp 171–173 °C (decomp.); 1H NMR (300 MHz, C6D6, 298 K): δ 1.02–1.67 (m, 48 H, CH(CH3)2), 3.21 (sept., 3JHH = 6.8 Hz, 2 H, CH(CH3)2), 3.51 (sept., 3JHH = 6.5 Hz, 6 H, CH(CH3)2), 7.02–7.25 (m, 14 H, NCH and Ar–H), Ga-H not observed; MS (EI), m/z (%): 445 (Ga(DAB)H+, 100), 377 (DABH+, 75); IR v/cm−1 (Nujol): 1878 br., s (Ga-H str.), 1665 s, 1595 s, 1563 s, 1354 s, 1316 m, 1256 m, 1210 m, 1100 m, 757 m.

Compound 2, [K(18-crown-6)][(Ar-DAB)GaIII{N(H)N=Fl}{(H)Fl}] (Fl = fluorendiyl), was obtained in low yield (9%) from the 1:2 reaction of [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)] with 9-diazofluorene (FlN2) in toluene in the presence of an excess of 18-crown-6 at 25 °C. Deep green crystals of 2 deposited from the reaction mixture after 2 h. At present, the mechanism of formation of 2 is unknown but presumably involves hydrogen abstraction from the reaction solvent. The compound displays negligible solubility in normal deuterated solvents. As a result meaningful NMR spectroscopic data for the compound could not be obtained. Mp 93–96 °C (decomp.); MS (EI), m/z (%): 445 (Ga(Ar-DAB)H+, 100), 377 (Ar-DABH+, 63); IR v/cm−1 (Nujol): 3365 m (N–H str.), 1666 s, 1593 s, 1563 s, 1355 s, 1316 m, 1256 m, 1210 m, 757 m; anal. calc. for C71H86N4GaKO6: C 71.05%, H 7.22%, N 4.67%; found: C 70.56%, H 7.01%, N 4.64%.

Compound 3, [K(OEt2)3][(Ar-DAB)GaII(CH2Ph)GaII(Ar-DAB)], was obtained in low yield (6%) from the 1:1 reaction of [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)] with [BrB(Ar-DAB)] in a mixture of diethyl ether and toluene at 25 °C. Deep red crystals of 3 deposited from the reaction mixture after 5 h. At present, the mechanism of formation of 3 is unknown, but it likely involves oxidation of the gallium(I) starting material by [BrB(Ar-DAB)] to give the known gallium(II) dimer, [{Ga(Ar-DAB)}2] [16]. The toluene solvent could then be deprotonated by an excess of the base, [K(tmeda)][:Ga(Ar-DAB)], yielding K[CH2Ph] which reacts with [{Ga(Ar-DAB)}2] to give compound 3. The compound displays negligible solubility in normal deuterated solvents. As a result meaningful NMR spectroscopic data for the compound could not be obtained. Mp 205–209 °C (decomp.); MS (EI), m/z (%): 889 ({Ga(Ar-DAB)}2H, 23), 445 (Ga(Ar-DAB)H+, 100), 377 (Ar-DABH+, 42); IR v/cm−1 (Nujol): 1666 w, 1587 s, 1351 s, 1316 m, 1259 m, 1098 s, 800 s, 758 m; anal. calc. for C71H109N4Ga2KO3: C 68.48%, H 8.82%, N 4.50%; found: C 68.12%, H 8.71%, N 4.48%.
